Award.AwardTitle: ARTS: Overcoming the nematode taxonomic impediment through integration of novel tools for species discovery and phylogeny: Cephaloboidea as a case-study
Award.AbstractNarration:
Human existence depends on soil, soil organisms and their processes; these are basic to sustaining environmental systems, agriculture and human well-being. Microscopic nematodes are a key component to soil systems: they are unmatched in species diversity, often with thousands of individuals in a handful of soil. Surprisingly, most nematode species remain hidden to science i.e. undiscovered and un-named; their species-specific environmental roles are generally not understood at a level useful to define, understand and sustain healthy ecosystems. This project will develop new DNA/microscopy technology to implement novel, efficient, cost-saving approaches to nematode species discovery and description, including evolutionary and ecological relationships. A California desert will be the experimental site for developing these tools, but the application and benefits are global.

Dramatically improving nematode identification tools will support soil ecologists and other biologists in the broader goals of understanding biological diversity and soil ecosystems for the benefit of humanity. The impact is broadened by developing online identification aids designed for non-specialists as well as for teaching tools. The project will train a graduate student and several undergraduates. Through small college collaboration it will provide research experience for female minority students. New instructional tools and training approaches involving soils will be developed for grades 5-12.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human existence depends on soil, soil organisms, and their processes. Yet nematodes, among the most abundant and diverse organisms in soil, remain its least known component. These nematode species are mostly undescribed, and before critical aspects of their biology can be understood, they must be discovered and characterized. For example, it is known that nematodes interact with soil microbes and invertebrate animals to facilitate decomposition, nutrient cycling, and other processes that contribute to soil structure. However, the ways that nematodes contribute to soil health cannot be understood without overcoming the impediments to understanding their biodiversity and developing rapid methods for species identification. Therefore, the goal of this research was to develop, test and implement novel approaches to rapidly identify soil nematode species and permit more efficient characterization of nematode biodiversity using methods involving DNA sequencing. 

To meet our research objectives and overcome technical obstacles, a desert soil study system was investigated. The study site, University of California Boyd Deep Canyon Reserve (DCR) is a protected research area that provides for long-term investigation. Nematodes were obtained from replicate samples of soils representing the root zones of three different common plants (Palo Verde, hummingbird bush, and creosote bush). Nematode samples were characterized by three different methods. In method one, high resolution images of individual nematodes were obtained using microscopy, and then the DNA of these same nematodes was sequenced. This approach provided a direct link between nematode structure and diagnostic DNA sequences. In the second method DNA sequences were obtained from hundreds of individual nematodes representing each soil sample, which provided information on the relative abundance of the different species. In the third method, DNA sequences were obtained from pools of thousands of nematodes. This approach included the largest number of nematodes per sample and used advanced DNA sequencing methods to evaluate the number of species present. 

These three approaches require different investments of effort and yield different kinds of information. Our study demonstrated that the third method is the most efficient and provides an excellent estimate of the number of nematode species per sample. However, this approach does not provide an accurate estimate of the relative proportions or absolute numbers of each species in a sample. This makes this high-volume approach less useful for certain ecological or agricultural studies where estimates of the absolute numbers of nematode species are needed (e.g., to predict levels of plant damage by plant-parasitic nematodes). The second method provides a good estimate of species diversity and abundance but is more labor intensive and expensive on a per sample basis. The first method is necessary to know what species names should be associated with a particular DNA sequence, or if new species should be described. For understanding the biodiversity and geographic distribution of nematodes in many soils, using both methods one and three will be sufficient. These two methods will vastly speed the characterization of nematode biodiversity in soil and other sediments where most nematodes live. For our study site at DCR, we have discovered species of nematodes that are new to science and learned that method three is also providing data on other soil organisms, including fungi, algae, rotifers and water bears. An important result of this project has been to train undergraduate and graduate students, technicians, and postdoctoral scientists in these methods. In addition, a workshop on methods of data analysis for the high-volume DNA-based methods has also advanced training. Outcomes of this project have improved tools for nematologists and soil ecologists to survey nematode biodiversity, to discover species, and to specifically identify taxa of great abundance and diversity with greater ease and accuracy.
